thread.title: Umpqua Community College gunman had rifle, 5 handguns, 5 magazines of ammo
thread.title_full: Umpqua Community College gunman had rifle, 5 handguns, 5 magazines of ammo | OregonLive.com

author: Maxine Bernstein | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Umpqua Community College gunman had rifle, 5 handguns, 5 magazines of ammo
text:
Christopher Sean Harper-Mercer, the 26-year-old gunman who killed nine people at Umpqua Community College, was heavily armed, carrying five handguns and one rifle to the campus Thursday.
Police recovered a flak jacket with steel plates lying beside the gunman's rifle that held five magazines of ammunition, authorities said Friday. Federal officials confirmed that he was armed with a variation of an AR-15, but he used a single handgun.
Harper-Mercer was enrolled in the class where the shooting occurred, the Douglas County Sheriff's Office said.
Among the nine people who died, most were fellow students. Three were age 18. One was a teacher, Lawrence Levine of Glide, 67, sheriff's officials confirmed. They also revised the number of wounded from seven to nine people.
The pain hit close to home, said Douglas County Fire Chief Greg Marlar of Fire District 2. Among the dead were Treven Anspach, 20, of Sutherlin, son of a local firefighter, and Rebecca Carnes, 18, of Myrtle Creek, a niece of a local paramedic, Marlar said.
"The situation is personal to us, and we share in the pain everyone is feeling right now,'' he said. His firefighters were the first on the scene.
Mark Graves | The Oregonian/OregonLive At the shooter's Winchester residence, authorities recovered seven more firearms and additional ammunition, said Celinez Nunez, U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and Explosives assistant special agent in charge.
All 13 weapons were traced to federal firearms dealers. The gunman or his family members bought seven of the guns within the past three years, Nunez said. A 14 th weapon had been traded back to the place where he bought it, she said.
"They were all purchased legally,'' Nunez said.
Douglas County Sheriff John Hanlin continued to avoid using the name of the shooter. He died after an exchange of gunfire with two members of the Roseburg Police Department. It's still not clear if he was hit by a police officer's bullet or turned his gun on himself.
"Again, you will not hear anyone from this law enforcement operation use his name,'' Hanlin said. "I continue to believe that those media and community members who publicize his name will only glorify his horrific actions and eventually this will only serve to inspire future acts.''
Hanlin wouldn't confirm if any notes were recovered from the shooter or discuss a motive in the killings. Asked by a reporter if Hanlin could identify a photo of the gunman shown on a cellphone, the sheriff said no.
Asked during a news conference if the number of weapons recovered from the shooter was unusual, the sheriff said, "In Oregon, this is a hunting state and firearms are popular.''
Cars on campus Anyone who has a car parked on the campus are asked to meet at the Douglas County Fairgrounds at 3 p.m. Friday to take buses back to the campus to retrieve them. The sheriff said deputies were assigned to families of the shooter's victims. "These families are living through the nightmare in the most personal way possible,'' Hanlin said.
Janet Holland, executive director of the Community Health Alliance, said the agency's offices will be open through the weekend from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. to allow anyone to come in for counseling.
Holland's son is a student at the college and was there Thursday. When he came home, she said, there were "lots of hugs" and she "let him talk about his experiences,'' which she encourages parents to do.
Roseburg City Manager Lance Colley called the shooting "something that we never hoped would happen anywhere, much less our community'' and thanked people from across the nation and beyond for their help and condolences.
"Support the families, certainly support the college, and help us all move forward,'' Colley said. "Keep the families in your prayers.''
The Umpqua Community College campus will reopen Monday, but classes will be canceled through Friday, Oct. 9.
-- Maxine Bernstein
mbernstein@oregonian.com
503-221-8212; @maxoregonian
